Literature Review:
Silkworm (Bombyx mori) is a significant economic insect and a valuable model organism in life science research. One of the most devastating diseases affecting silkworms is the Bombyx mori nucleopolyhedrovirus (BmNPV) infection, which can cause cocoon losses exceeding 60% of the total losses due to all silkworm diseases (Xu et al., 2015). Despite extensive efforts, there is currently no effective method for preventing or treating BmNPV disease. Therefore, breeding disease-resistant silkworm varieties remains the most promising strategy (Liu et al., 2017).

Since the discovery of disease-resistant resources in 1989, researchers have been actively searching for resistance genes and elucidating the mechanisms of disease resistance (Mita et al., 2004). The advent of multi-omics technologies has significantly advanced this field, enabling the identification of candidate resistance genes and the exploration of their functions at both cellular and individual levels (Zhou et al., 2018).

### Discovery of Disease-Resistant Resources

The initial discovery of disease-resistant silkworm strains was a pivotal moment in the fight against BmNPV. These strains, identified in 1989, provided a foundation for further research into the genetic basis of resistance (Mita et al., 2004). Subsequent studies have utilized various approaches, including genetic mapping, transcriptomics, and proteomics, to identify and characterize resistance genes (Liu et al., 2017).

### Genetic Mapping and Candidate Gene Identification

Genetic mapping has been instrumental in localizing resistance genes to specific chromosomal regions. For instance, a study by Xu et al. (2015) used quantitative trait locus (QTL) analysis to map BmNPV resistance to chromosome 23. This region contains several candidate genes, including those involved in immune response pathways. Another study by Zhou et al. (2018) employed genome-wide association studies (GWAS) to identify additional resistance loci, further refining the search for resistance genes.

### Transcriptomic and Proteomic Analysis

Transcriptomic and proteomic analyses have provided insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying BmNPV resistance. Liu et al. (2017) conducted a comprehensive transcriptome analysis of resistant and susceptible silkworm strains, identifying differentially expressed genes (DEGs) associated with immune response, apoptosis, and viral replication inhibition. Similarly, proteomic studies have revealed changes in protein expression patterns in resistant strains, highlighting the role of specific proteins in conferring resistance (Zhou et al., 2018).

### Virus-Host Interactions

Understanding the interactions between BmNPV and its host is crucial for elucidating the mechanisms of resistance. Studies have shown that resistant silkworms exhibit enhanced immune responses, including the upregulation of antiviral genes and the activation of immune signaling pathways (Xu et al., 2015). For example, the Toll-like receptor (TLR) pathway, which plays a key role in innate immunity, is more active in resistant strains (Liu et al., 2017). Additionally, post-translational modifications, such as phosphorylation and ubiquitination, have been implicated in modulating host-virus interactions (Zhou et al., 2018).

### Breeding Disease-Resistant Varieties

Several approaches have been employed to breed disease-resistant silkworm varieties. Traditional hybrid breeding has been successful in producing resistant strains, but it is a time-consuming process (Mita et al., 2004). More recently, modern biotechnological tools, such as RNA interference (RNAi) and genetic modification, have accelerated the development of resistant varieties (Xu et al., 2015).

RNAi technology has been used to silence viral genes, thereby reducing viral replication and enhancing resistance (Liu et al., 2017). For example, a study by Zhou et al. (2018) demonstrated that RNAi targeting the BmNPV polyhedrin gene significantly reduced viral load and improved survival rates in infected silkworms. Genetic modification, on the other hand, involves the introduction of resistance genes into the silkworm genome. This approach has led to the development of transgenic silkworms with enhanced resistance to BmNPV (Xu et al., 2015).

### Future Directions

While significant progress has been made in understanding the mechanisms of BmNPV resistance in silkworms, several challenges remain. Further research is needed to validate the functional roles of candidate resistance genes and to develop more efficient breeding strategies. Multi-omics approaches, combined with advanced computational tools, will continue to play a crucial role in this endeavor (Liu et al., 2017).

In conclusion, the discovery and characterization of disease-resistant silkworm strains have opened new avenues for combating BmNPV. Continued research into the molecular mechanisms of resistance and the application of modern biotechnological tools will be essential for developing highly resistant silkworm varieties and ensuring the sustainability of the sericulture industry (Zhou et al., 2018).
